title: The Crown star Josh O'Connor reveals how playing future king changed him into a ROYALIST
text:
He is best known as the eldest Durrell son Larry in the hit ITV series.

But Josh O'Connor's newest role is set to propel him to global stardom as he takes on Prince Charles in series three and four of The Crown.

The 29-year-old actor was born in Hampshire to a 'very lefty' family who weren't enamoured by the royals.

But he said playing the endearing part has changed his perception to royalty.

Josh O'Connor's (right) newest role is set to propel him to global stardom as he takes on Prince Charles in series three and four of The Crown. He will star alongside Olivia Colman as Queen Elizabeth (pictured filming the 1969 investiture ceremony)

He is best known as the eldest Durrell son Larry in the hit ITV series

'I guess I'm republican in nature, but I'd say I've gone full circle and become a royalist, which is the first time I've said that,' he told The Telegraph Magazine.

He also told how his reaction to landing the coveted role wasn't quite what people might expect.

He said: 'I always had in mind a Spitting Image version of him as a bumbling caricature, a bit of a national joke, so in that sense I wasn't interested.'

Regardless of his apprehension, O'Connor took on the immense role - in which he would play son to former co-star Olivia Colman's Queen Elizabeth.

O'Connor played Marius and Coleman Madame Thénardier in the BBC's adaptation of Victor Hugo's novel.

One of the powerful scenes the pair star in together in The Crown is a recreation of Prince Charles' 1969 investiture ceremony at in Caernarfon Castle.

He will star alongside Emma Corrin as Diana in series four (the pair pictured together during filming)

The 29-year-old actor was born in Hampshire to a 'very lefty' family who weren't enamoured by the royals. Pictured: O'Connor playing Prince Charles for a scene in the series (left). Right: Prince Charles pictured at a microphone as he speaks after playing a game of Polo at Warwick Farm Racecourse near Sydney in 1983

In May 1969, just two months before his investiture, Charles, then just 20 years old, received a note from his grandmother Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother in which she expressed her support.

She wrote: 'My darling Charles, I can't tell you what charming and heart-warming things I am always hearing about you.

'Everyone loves you and is proud of you and I absolutely know you will be able to do wonderful things for this country.

O'Connor said: 'I always had in mind a Spitting Image version of him as a bumbling caricature, a bit of a national joke, so in that sense I wasn't interested'

'Not only in leadership but by being your own kind-hearted, loving and intelligent and funny self.'

The ceremony saw Prince Charles receive the title the Prince Of Wales and Earldom of Chester, which 500 million people watched on TV in Britain and around the globe.

It was in effect Charles’s first public step towards the Throne, and during the event the Letters Patent were read in Welsh before the Queen invested him with the girdle, sword, coronet, ring, rod and kingly mantle.

The first series of The Crown was one of the most critically acclaimed dramas of 2016 - winning two Golden Globes and two SAG awards, and being nominated for four BAFTAs.

The show is the most expensive television series ever made - with the first series costing $100million.

The Crown Season 3 launches globally on Sunday, November 17.
description: The actor, 29, from Hampshire, was born to a 'very lefty' family who weren't enamoured by the royals. He said the endearing role has made him go 'full circle' and he is now a 'royalist'.
